info.description:
This Application Programming Interface (API) Specification describes how to use the DME REST API.

The DME REST API allows you to upload and download data, manage associated metadata, and search for assets against these metadata. 

A *collection* is a logical directory in DME. A *data file* represents an individual data object. Data files reside in collections. Collections can also contain other collections. You can logically structure collections and data files in a hierarchical manner, depicted with a tree structure with parents and children.

A *metadata attribute* consists of the attribute name and the attribute value. Each object or collection has associated metadata (required or user defined). When you create a collection or object, you must provide any required metadata.

For each collection, use the collection_type attribute to define the collection type. 

A *child* entity (collection or data file) always inherits the metadata of its parent and other ancestors in that hierarchy. This facilitates advanced searches where you can search for data files or collections based on their own metadata or their parent metadata. You can also limit searches to a specific level in the hierarchy.

A *fileContainerId* is the Globus endpoint UUID or AWS S3 bucket name. 

A *fileId*, when registering data to DME, is the full path of the file or collection which exists at the Globus or AWS S3 location. When downloading data to a Globus endpoint or to an AWS S3 bucket, *fileId* is the destination file name or collection name.
info.title: DME API

get.description:
This API specification assumes you will be specifying your username and password with each command. However, if you would like to generate an authentication token instead, this service allows you do so.
1. **CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/authenticate -u <Your-User-ID>
  ```
2. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/authenticate -u My-User-ID
  ```
  
  Example Token from Console Output:
  
  ```
  **********************************************************.******************************************
  ```

After the command returns the token, create a *curl-conf* file and save the generated token in that file, as follows:
  ```
-H "Authorization:Bearer *Authentication token*"
  ```

3. **EXAMPLE - *curl-conf* File**
  ```
  -H "Authorization:Bearer **********************************************************.******************************************"
  ```
4. **EXAMPLE - Using Authentication Token With Curl Commands**
   Instead of using the *-u* parameter to specify your username, use the *--config* parameter to specify the path to the *curl-conf* file. 
  ```
  curl --config folder/curl-conf -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/download/13163eac-be40-4f31-af23-e030b905c61a' -D header.txt -o output.json
  ```

This service allows you to get the status of a registration task. The *taskId* parameter is the task identifier returned in the *Registration* REST API response. 

This service returns the status and path of each file in DME.

1. **CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/v2/registration/{taskId}' -D header.txt -o output.json -u <Your-User-ID>
  ```

  2. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/v2/registration/32b79929-bd25-4393-a1a3-d64195bb4dea' -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
  ```
get.summary: Get the status of a registration task.

401.description:
Authentication Failure: 

HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized Content-Type: application/json


JSON:

"message": "Access Denied: LDAP authentication failed",

"stackTrace": "…" }

get.description:
This service allows you to get the status of a collection download task. The *taskId* parameter is the task identifier returned in the *Collection Download* REST API response. 

This service returns the download status of each file in DME.

1. **CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/collection/download/{taskId}' -D header.txt -o output.json -u <Your-User-ID>
  ```

  2. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/collection/download/e1fc3394-f079-4f50-b3e2-8890acb0f8a5' -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
  ```
get.summary: Get the status of a collection download task.

get.description:
This service allows you to get the status of a data file download task. The *taskId* parameter is the task identifier returned in the *Data File Download* REST API response. 

This service returns the download status of each data file in DME.
1. **CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/dataObject/download/{taskId}' -D header.txt -o output.json -u <Your-User-ID>
  ```

  2. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/dataObject/download/c09b52f3-050c-4755-90c6-44d6edbd0c52' -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
  ```
get.summary: Get the status of a data file download task.

get.description:
This service allows you to get the status of a data file list download task or a collection list download task. The *taskId* parameter is the task identifier returned in the *Download Object and Collection List* REST API response. 
This service returns the download status of each file. For collection list, the service also returns the collection summary information.

1.**CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/download/{taskId}' -D header.txt -o output.json -u <Your-User-ID>
  ```

  2. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/download/96870f99-4702-4e89-acc6-3e80bd2f5102' -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
  ```
get.summary: Get the status of a data file list download task or a collection list download task.

get.description:
This service allows you to get information about a specific collection including all of its hierarchical metadata. Use the *path* parameter to specify the path to the collection of interest. In the output, the *collection* and *selfMetadataEntries* elements provide information about the collection you specified, while the *parentMetadataEntries* element provides information about the collection that contains the collection you specified. If you set the *list* parameter to 'true', the *subCollections* element lists the child collections of this collection and the *dataObjects* element lists the data files of this collection. The list parameter is optional and its default is 'false'. 

**Query Param**
*list* – If set to 'true', the API lists the child collections and data files of this collection. The *subCollections* element lists the child collections and the *dataObjects* element lists the data files. This is an optional parameter and default is 'false'.

1. **CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/collection/{path}' -D header.txt -o output.json -u <Your-User-ID>
  ```

  2. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/collection/NCI_DOE_Archive/Program_3_1_21/Study_3_1_21/Asset_3_1_21?list=true -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
  ```

post.description:
This service allows you to perform a query for a collection. You can perform a simple query, or you can combine multiple simple queries into a compound query.

  **Example Simple Query**
          
    ...
    {
       "attribute": "experiment",
       "value": "H1_M2_update_10M",
       "operator": "EQUAL"
    }
    ...

This example consists of the following parameters:
  
  • *attribute* - Specify the name of the metadata attribute that you want to query.
    
  • *value* - Specify the value of the metadata attribute that you want to query.
    
  • *operator* - When using a comparison operator, supported operators are: EQUAL, NOT_EQUAL, LIKE, NUM_LESS_THAN, NUM_LESS_OR_EQUAL, NUM_GREATER_OR_EQUAL, NUM_GREATER_THAN.  

**Example Simple Query with *attributeMatch***
          
    ...
    {
       "attributeMatch": "ANY",
       "value": "H1_M2_update_10M",
       "operator": "EQUAL"
    }
    ...

This example consists of the following parameters:

  • *attributeMatch* - This is an optional attribute. If you set this attribute to *ANY*, then the query applies to any metadata attribute, and the system expects you to omit the ‘attribute’ parameter from the query. Omitting the ‘attributeMatch’ parameter, or setting it to EXACT, limits the search to the provided metadata attribute.

  • *operator* - When using *attributeMatch*, supported comparison operators are the same as above.

  **Example Simple Query with *levelFilter***
          
    ...
    {
       "attributeMatch": "ANY",
       "value": "H1_M2_update_10M",
       "operator": "EQUAL",
       "levelFilter": {
         "level": 1,
         "operator": "NOT_EQUAL"
       }
    }
    ...

This example consists of the following parameters:

  • *levelFilter* - This is an optional attribute. If you use the levelFilter attribute, search matches the metadata found at the specified *level*. Otherwise, the query matches metadata found at any level of the path.
    
  • *operator* - When using *levelFilter*, supported comparison operators are the same as above.  
    
**Example Compound Query with Additional Parameters**
    
A simple query is the basic building block of the compound query. You can combine multiple simple queries with a join operator ("AND", "OR") to create a list of queries. You can further combine multiple lists to create a combined query. 

    {
       "compoundQuery": {
         "operator": "AND",
         "queries": [{
             "attributeMatch": "ANY",
             "value": "H1_M2_update_10M",
             "operator": "EQUAL",
             "levelFilter": {
               "level": 1,
               "operator": "NOT_EQUAL"
             }
           },
           {
             "attribute": "run_name",
             "value": "run_02_20_2020",
             "operator": "LIKE"
           }
         ]
       },
       "detailedResponse": true,
       "page": 2,
       "pageSize": 10,
       "totalCount": true
    }

This example contains the following additional parameters:

  • *detailedResponse*: By default, a search returns only paths of matching collections. If you set this attribute to *true*, the system returns collections with metadata.
  
  • *page*: Ask for a specific page of results. By default, the query returns the first 100 results in page 1, the second 100 in page 2, and so on. If you omit the page parameter, the system fetches page 1. 
  
  • *pageSize*: By default, the query returns up to 100 results in each page.
  
  • *totalCount*: If you set this parameter to *true*, the system returns the total count of collections matching the query regardless of the query limit and page. By default, if you omit this attribute, the system sets it to *false* and does not return a total count.
  
  
  
  
  
  

  1. **CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d @<attributesFile.json> -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/collection/query -H "Accept: application/json" -D  <response-header> -o <response-message.json> -u <Your-User-ID>
  
  ```
  2.  **attributesFile.json Example**
  ```
       {
         "compoundQuery": {
           "operator": "AND",
           "queries": [{
               "attribute": "access_group",
               "value": "public",
               "operator": "NOT_EQUAL"
             },
             {
               "attribute": "collection_type",
               "value": "Asset",
               "operator": "EQUAL"
             }
           ]
         },
         "detailedResponse": true,
         "page": 2,
         "pageSize": 10,
         "totalCount": true
       }
  ```
  3. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d @attributesFile.json -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/collection/query -H "Accept: application/json" -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
  ```
post.summary: Find a collection by metadata query.

```
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 2023 19:59:58 GMT

```

post.description:
This service allows you to generate a *download request URL* that you can then use to download the data file directly from DME using wget or other commands. 
 


 1. **CURL COMMAND**
    ```
    curl -k -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/dataObject/{path}/generateDownloadRequestURL -u <Your-User-ID>
    ```
2. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
    ```
    curl -k -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/dataObject/NCI_DOE_Archive/ATOM/Neurocrine_H1_Demonstration/H1_M2_update_10nM/H1_M2_10nM_update_20210308.csv/generateDownloadRequestURL -u My-User-ID
    
   
    DownloadRequestURL Response Example:
    
   {"downloadRequestURL":"http://s3-nci-north.ha.nci.nih.gov/dme-nci-doe-prod-cld/NCI_DOE/NCI_DOE_Archive/ATOM/Neurocrine_H1_Demonstration/H1_M2_update_10nM/H1_M2_10nM_update_20210308.csv?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Date=20210324T183709Z&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-Credential=113504398e2081835f43%2F20210324%2Fnci-north%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Signature=449f448f26758fb8f830603c7a43963550cb802292adcb90317cadff14739526"}
    ``` 
    
3. **WGET COMMAND**
    ```
    wget -O OutputFileName “DownloadRequestURL”
    ``` 
 
 
4. **EXAMPLE - WGET COMMAND**
    ```
   wget -O OutputFileName “http://s3-nci-north.ha.nci.nih.gov/dme-nci-doe-prod-cld/NCI_DOE/NCI_DOE_Archive/ATOM/Neurocrine_H1_Demonstration/H1_M2_update_10nM/H1_M2_10nM_update_20210308.csv?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Date=20210324T183709Z&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&X-Amz-Expires=604800&X-Amz-Credential=113504398e2081835f43%2F20210324%2Fnci-north%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Signature=449f448f26758fb8f830603c7a43963550cb802292adcb90317cadff14739526”
    ```

post.description:
This service allows you to perform a query for a data file. You can perform a simple query, or you can combine multiple simple queries into a compound query.

  **Example Simple Query**
          
    ...
    {
       "attribute": "experiment",
       "value": "H1_M2_update_10M",
       "operator": "EQUAL"
    }
    ...

This example consists of the following parameters:

  • *attribute* - Specify the name of the metadata attribute that you want to query.
    
  • *value* - Specify the value of the metadata attribute that you want to query.
    
  • *operator* - When using a comparison operator with *attribute* and *value*, supported operators are: EQUAL, NOT_EQUAL, LIKE, NUM_LESS_THAN, NUM_LESS_OR_EQUAL, NUM_GREATER_OR_EQUAL, NUM_GREATER_THAN.  

**Example Simple Query with *attributeMatch***
          
    ...
    {
       "attributeMatch": "ANY",
       "value": "H1_M2_update_10M",
       "operator": "EQUAL"
    }
    ...
    
This example consists of the following parameters:

  • *attributeMatch* - This is an optional attribute. If you set this attribute to *ANY*, then the query applies to any metadata attribute, and the system expects you to omit the ‘attribute’ parameter from the query. Omitting the ‘attributeMatch’ parameter, or setting it to EXACT, limits the search to the provided metadata attribute.

  • *operator* - When using *attributeMatch*, supported comparison operators are the same as above.  

  **Example Simple Query with *levelFilter***
          
    ...
    {
       "attributeMatch": "ANY",
       "value": "H1_M2_update_10M",
       "operator": "EQUAL",
       "levelFilter": {
         "level": 1,
         "operator": "NOT_EQUAL"
       }
    }
    ...

This example consists of the following parameters:

  • *levelFilter* - This is an optional attribute. If you use the levelFilter attribute, search matches the metadata found at the specified *level*. Otherwise, the query matches metadata found at any level of the path.
    
  • *operator* - When using *levelFilter*, supported comparison operators are the same as above.  
    
**Example Compound Query with Additional Parameters**

A simple query is the basic building block of the compound query. You can combine multiple simple queries with a join operator ("AND", "OR") to create a list of queries. You can further combine multiple lists to create a combined query.  

    {
      "compoundQuery": {
        "operator": "AND",
        "queries": [{
            "attributeMatch": "ANY",
            "value": "H1_M2_update_10M",
            "operator": "EQUAL",
            "levelFilter": {
              "level": 1,
              "operator": "NOT_EQUAL"
            }
          },
          {
            "attribute": "run_name",
            "value": "run_02_20_2020",
            "operator": "LIKE"
          }
        ]
      },
      "detailedResponse": true,
      "page": 2,
      "pageSize": 10,
      "totalCount": true
    }

This example contains the following additional parameters:

  • *detailedResponse*: By default, a search returns only paths of matching data files. If you set this attribute to *true*, the system returns data files with their metadata.
  
  • *page*: Ask for a specific page of results. By default, the query returns the first 100 results in page 1, the second 100 in page 2, and so on. If you omit the page parameter, the system fetches page 1. 
  
  • *pageSize*: By default, the query returns up to 100 results in each page.
  
  • *totalCount*: If you set this parameter to *true*, the system returns the total count of data files matching the query regardless of the query limit and page. By default, if you omit this attribute, the system sets it to 'false' and does not return a total count.


1. **CURL COMMAND**
```
curl -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d @<attributesFile.json> -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/dataobject/query -H "Accept: application/json" -D  <response-header> -o <response-message.json> -u <Your-User-ID>
```
2.  **attributesFile.json Example**
```
  {
    "compoundQuery": {
      "operator": "AND",
      "queries": [{
          "attribute": "asset_identifier",
          "value": "H1_Selectivity_Asset",
          "operator": "LIKE"
        },
        {
          "attribute": "data_transfer_status",
          "value": "ARCHIVED",
          "operator": "EQUAL"
        }
      ]
    },
    "page": 2,
    "pageSize": 10,
    "totalCount": true
  }
```
3. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
```
curl -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d @attributesFile.json -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/dataObject/query -H "Accept: application/json" -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
```

get.description:
This service allows you to get information about a specific data file including all of its hierarchical metadata. Use the *path* parameter to specify the path to the data file of interest. In the output, the *dataObject* and *selfMetadataEntries* elements provide information about the file you specified, while the *parentMetadataEntries* element provides information about the collection that contains the file you specified.

1. **CURL COMMAND**

  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/v2/dataObject/{path}' -D header.txt -o output.json -u <Your-User-ID>
  ```
  2. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND**
  ```
  curl -k 'https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/v2/dataObject/FNL_SF_Archive/PI_Lab_JaneDoe/Project1/data.txt' -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
  ```

post.description:
This service allows you to transfer a data file from DME to one of the following possible destinations: 
 
 

• Local system (synchronous download) 

• Globus endpoint (asynchronous download) 

• AWS S3 (asynchronous download) 


 The *path* parameter represents the logical path of the data file registered with DME. When downloading files asynchronously (to a Globus endpoint or to an S3 bucket), the attributesFile.json must have the destination information as shown in the *attributesFile.json* example above. 



A DME user account is a pre-requisite for downloading data from DME.  

For downloading to a Globus endpoint, if you set the optional *destinationOverwrite* indicator to ‘true’ and if the destination file exists, this service overwrites the destination file. If you omit this indicator and the destination file exists, then this service rejects the transfer request. 

Additionally, for downloading to a Globus endpoint, add the **HPCDME-PROD-App-Accts-Pool-FNLCR** group to your Globus endpoint and give that group the *WRITE* permission. For details, refer to [Preparing to Use Globus](https://wiki.nci.nih.gov/x/ngLgGQ) wiki page.



  1. **CURL COMMAND**
   ```
  curl -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d @<attributesFile.json> -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/v2/dataObject/{path}/download -H "Accept: application/json" -D  <response-header> -o <response-message.json> -u <Your-User-ID>
  ``` 
  
  2.  **JSON FILE EXAMPLES**
  ``` 
  a. To request download to your local system
                
        { 
        }
  
  b. To request a download to a Globus endpoint
  
      {
        "globusDownloadDestination": {
          "destinationLocation": {
          "fileContainerId": "4a3b132a-815f-11e7-8dff-22000b9923ef",
            "fileId": "demo-file-3-20-21"
          },
       "destinationOverwrite" : true,
        }
      }
     
      
 c.   To request a download to an S3 bucket
 
        {
            "s3DownloadDestination": {
              "destinationLocation": {
                "fileContainerId": "demo-NCI-1",
                "fileId": "demo-file-3-20-21"
              },
              "account" : {
                "accessKey" : "***",
                "secretKey" : "***",
                "region" :"us-east-1",
              },
          "destinationURL" : “https://...”
            }
        }
  ```
  3. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND to download a file to a Globus endpoint**
  ```
  curl -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d @attributesFile.json -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/v2/dataObject/NCI_DOE_Archive/Program_3_1_21/Study_3_1_21/Asset_Data_3_1_21/anl_drug_moa_information.xlsx/download -H "Accept: application/json" -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
  ```
  
  
  4. **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND to download a file to an S3 bucket**
  
  
  ```
  curl -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d @aattributesFile.json -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/v2/dataObject/NCI_DOE_Archive/Program_3_1_21/Study_3_1_21/Asset_Data_3_1_21/anl_drug_moa_information.xlsx/download -H "Accept: application/json" -D header.txt -o output.json -u My-User-ID
  ```
  
  
  
  5.  **EXAMPLE - CURL COMMAND to download a file to your local system**
  ```
  curl -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d @attributesFile.json -X POST https://fsdmel-dsapi01t.ncifcrf.gov:7738/hpc-server/v2/dataObject/NCI_DOE_Archive/Program_3_1_21/Study_3_1_21/Asset_Data_3_1_21/anl_drug_moa_information.xlsx/download -H "Accept: application/json" -D header.txt -o output.xlsx -u My-User-ID
  ```
